title: Using Pseudo Feedback to Improve Cross-Lingual Ontology Mapping

introducer: Jens Wissmann, School of Informatics, City University London
author: Bo Fu, Trinity College Dublin

segmentation: Our next speaker is miss full from Trinity College Dublin.
My name is Bo.
I am a PhD student under the supervision of Robin Declan, Intrinsic College, Dublin, Ireland.
My talk today is titled using Pseudo Feedback to improve cross lingual Ontology mapping.
This is an overview of my talk in the next 20 minutes, so we're quickly introduced the concept of crossing ontology mapping.
We talk about some of the related work in the field and then to address 1 of the challenges we identified.
We proposed a pseudo feedback mechanism and we will show some of the initial evaluation results and then we'll conclude with some of the suggestions for future research directions.
This field.
There are three obvious questions we need to ask ourselves before we talk about the specifics.
First of all, crossing, well, intelligent, mapping.
What is it?
Why do we need it, and what are the benefits?

First of all, we identify cross lingual entology mapping as a process to establish relationships among ontological resource is between two or more independent ontologies where each one is labeled in a different natural language.
But why do we need to do that?
Because some I say one approach to ontology construction is to use.
Natural language neutral labels to label the concept.
In our case, there would be little need for crossing on teologi mapping.
However, in reality that's not what we're seeing at the moment.
There is drivers from industry as well as academia as we could see, there's the trend in multilingual semantic web where I was just the emergence of multilingual ontologies.

Under from industry driver we could see their mounting organisations such as the Food Agriculture Organization from the United Nations whereby they have made some significant effort in establishing ontology based systems and because they have to make all of their official documents available in various natural languages they've always been seeking ways to support Multilinguality ontologies.
In academia we see some new research trends such as ontology localization and linguistic enrichment of ontologies.
So all of these efforts kind of highlight the importance of providing a support to map ontologies that are in different natural languages.
The benefits of that, for example, is that we could better support the management of digital content as well as to support new ways of semantic search, for example.
Also, we could perhaps enhance user experience personalization and adaptation in multilingual user models, for example.
Um, so these are the some of the related works in this field.
I will talk about each of these approach.
With an example next.
So first of all, manual crossing won't holiday mapping it straight forward.
So you basically just create mappings by hand.
The obvious advantage of Daddy is the mapping is generated would be highly likely to be accurate and reliable.
However this could be a very expensive process.
A second approach is to use corpus based.
Approach whereby you use bilingual corpora.
Before you generate ontology mapping results.
So the advantage of that is like some like bilingual corpora that's often used in machine translation.
This doesn't necessarily have to be parallel, however.
The disadvantage of that is you this is heavily based on synsets, which is only evident in so sorry, but not necessarily formally defined ontologies in RDF and out.
Also, because you need to construct these parallel corpora beforehand, which meant there's construction overhead.
Also, there is an issue with the coverage of these corpora.
Uh, so.

Really, there is the language schmundt linguistic enrichment of ontologies whereby currently there already choose available, such as the underlying plug-in that's already downloadable for Prodigy, where during the development phase of the ontology you could enrich the concepts with linguistic evidence.
This approach would provide the mapping process with a lot more strong evidence, including mappings.
However, as the authors have already pointed out, this is currently an standardized process.
Which meant building systems and frameworks on top of this.
Linguistically enriching ontologies is slightly difficult in practice.
There is also the indirect alignment approach, whereby it's just the reuse of mappings.
This is not new concept already.
This is being proposed before, so imagine if you had three ontologies AB&C.
If you already have mappings between A&B as well as B&C, then to generate mappings between NC you just need to reuse the mappings that are already there.
So the advantage of this approach is that technically it's very easy to achieve.
However it relies on the existence of crossing apology mapping results.
Which currently remains a challenge in itself.

So Lastly, there is a a very dominated approach in this field, whereby translation is used to turn to convert a cross lingual mapping problem into a monolingual mapping problem by using tools such as abiding with dictionary mounting with the story, and I'm teachers for example, and then using a subsequent step from using monolingual.
How's your matching tools to solve the problem?
So what are the disadvantage?
Of this approach.
In a previous work we've submitted to a I soluci, we investigate the impact of machine translation, how that would impact on the subsequent monolingual matching step.

What we found out is that sometimes noise can be introduced in this first translation process, and we came up with a concept called Cross appropriate Ontology label translation, whereby the translations are selected to ensure the success of the subsequent monolingual ontology matching.

Approach step so we have shown some initial positive findings from the concept of a Lt and so in this paper we aim to improve that using pseudo feedback mechanism and one thing I should note here is that when I say label translation, what I meant is the segment that's used to identify the concept in an ontology.
So our inspiration is from how relevance feedback is used in the field of information retrieval.
Broadly speaking, there are three different types of relevance feedback.

Explicit feedback is when the system asks the user specifically to rate the relevance of the initial documents that were generated by the system, and then based on this feedback, generate a second set of documents that are supposedly better and implicit.
Feedback is when you try to do this process.
Based on how you could infer from users behaviors such as clicking actions and browser history, things like that and Lastly pseudo feedback is obviously to try to make this feedback.
Generate this feedback without the involvement of the user or the system automatically assumes the relevancy of the document.
So using explicit feedback has already been explored in the paper that I referenced here, it's a modeling montage matching process.
They've already shown the effect of.
Feedback in ontology mapping.
But in this paper specifically we want to investigate how the user does not have to be involved and how this pseudo feedback can be used in cross.
Oncology mapping in the field of IR relevance suddaby back pseudo feedback can be summarized into as in three step process.
In the first step, the system would generate an initial set of documents and second step.
The system assumes which of these documents are relevant and then Lastly based on this assumption it will generate a better set of documents.
So inspired by this, in the context of crossing ontology mapping, we understood the use of pseudo feedback as a three step process as well.
Firstly, we generate an initial set of matches.
Secondly, we try to guess in these initial matches that were generated just how correct they are.
So based on this assumption, we would aim to generate a second set of matches that are perhaps better than the initial set.

So this is an implementation of the approach that we propose, so starting from the top, if you were given to ontologies that are labeled in different natural language, is what you could do is from the Source Ontology side.
You could extract the labels from the ontology and then you could send that to a empty service.
In this case we integrated the Google Translate API and the Windows Live translator and also using the structures of ontology.
Each node in the ontology.
Environment so called surrounding can be generated and all of that is stored in the lexicon repository from the right hand side using a general framework.

Again, you can extract the labels and then the surroundings from a target ontology and then we generated synonyms for the ontology labels that appeared in the target ontology using Word net and also in addition to the surroundings.
All of that is stored in a lexicon repository.

So to select the appropriate translation, what we did is to for each label that needs to be translated from the Source Ontology side, we compare that to what is stored in a lexicon posture and hoping to find hints of which translation are perhaps more more appropriate.

And in the case where no assistance can be found, we then just send the Kennedy translations that were generated from the empty tool to Wikipedia using the Yahoo term extraction tool with, then extract.
Interpretive keywords for these candidate translations.

And when appropriate translations are determined, you then just have to create a copy of the source Ontology using the original structure, and then the monolingual ontology matching step is achieved by using the Alignment API, which is developed by area.

And finally, the assessment process is the where the pseudo feedback is generated, whereby we guess which matches are correct based on the confidence levels that were generated from the matching tool.
We then send this feedback back into the system and currently that involves in finding out which empty two to use for the 2nd.
Iteration of the system.

So an issue, a problem, a challenge that could happen here is that when you try to determine the appropriate translations, collision could happen when two or more concepts happen to choose the same translation as it's appropriate translation.
So in that case the system we're always prioritized, the one that came from the target ontology, such as the first four scenarios in the table here showed that.
However, it could happen that two collided terms came from the same level of strategy.
In our case, the system just let's the second one just choose an alternative translate.
And.
I'm to evaluate the approach we applied the implementation in a crossing montage mapping scenario.
The datasets we used here is taken from the OEE benchmark twenty 09, whereby the ontologies are labeled in English and French ontology.
OEI 101 is in English.
Oh yeah, 206 is in French.
These ontologies cover the general domain, kind of like conferences, meetings, things like that and we use the two systems to generate matches.

The first one being the implemented framework that I just showed earlier where it uses pseudo feedback to influence the quality of the match is generated and the baseline system doesn't use the pseudo feedback so effectively the baseline system is the first iteration of the system and the one with the pseudo feedback is the 2nd iteration of the system.
So here's an example of what pseudo feedback perhaps look like.
You don't need to rate this.
The important thing here to understand is that the so feedback is generated for a specific matching algorithm.
In this case, this one is provided by the Alignment API and we.
This stores the assumption that was used in a pseudo feedback.
In this case, all of the matches with confidence measure of at least .5 were considered as correct and then based on this assumption, we count how many matches were generated.

And based on the assumption, we determine how many of them were correct, so effectively we then have created a ranked list of empty choose that can should be used or prioritized in a second iteration of the system, so they would then be used in the appropriate translation determ.
Nation process.
So these sort of results generated from that experiment, the top there.
Those are different matching algorithms.
There are eight of them that were provided by the Alignment API, and the diagrams here.
The three of them.
The first one I laughed, shows the position scores.
The one in the middle shows the recall scores, and finally F measure takes both of these into account.
As you could see here, across all different type of matching algorithms, we were able to show any improvement in position.
Recall consequently, the F measure scores generated and one thing I'd like to note here is that this is even more of a improvement comparing to our previous system that uses the.
Uses the appropriate translation selection process in the generation of the ontology.
So in addition to study position reconnect measure, we also looked at the confidence levels of these correct matches that were generated.
So a good quality matching would be one that has a high confidence mean but a low standard deviation.
So what that effectively means is that the matches generated were not only more confident, but also the confidence levels were less dispersed.
So the diagram on the left basically where you want to be is the top left corner.
But you don't want to be at the bottom right corner as you could see.
Here we can see a very obvious improvement in the system that uses pseudo feedback.
So we, in addition to all of these previous evaluations, we also carried out a statistical test.
We use two tailed paired T tests to determine whether there is a significant significant difference between the two systems.

So with the null hypothesis being that there is no difference at all, and the alternative being that there is a difference, so the P value generated was smaller than .5, so it gives us more confidence to conclude.
That the system using pseudo feedback was much more better than the one that didn't.

So what we've concluded from this piece of research so far is that we have seen some preliminary evaluation results that were quite positive to our finding and the pseudo feedback mechanism can be effective in crossing 1 holiday mapping scenarios.
However, there are limitations in this research, mainly in three areas, first of all.
The implementation of the feedback mechanism so far we've only investigated pseudo feedback.
It would be interesting to see how explicit and implicit feedback could perhaps influence the quality of the matches in the future also.
We've also just didn't investigate whether.
The cutoff point can be configured or not, but since then we have done that in our later implementation of the approach then from the.
So from the from the experiment aspect, we haven't really applied in this specific work.
We haven't really applied with any other natural languages since then.
We have experimented with Japanese, German and Chinese.
So we we we use them to these languages, we believe we're a good representation of compareable as well as distinct natural languages.
And also we've experimented with very large ontology sites sets to determine the scalability of the system.
Lastly, the evaluation approach we didn't investigate when a when a.
Incorrect assumption was made how that could effect on the final mapping quality.
Also it would.
That would be interesting to see in the future and.
And Lastly, we've only carried out two iteration of the system.
It would be interesting to see if a third 4th, so an iteration of the system could add to the quality at all, if at all.
So this brings us to the.
End of my presentation.
Thank you very.
For your attention.
Questions.

Another translation.

Currently I'm not aware of such tool, but if you could be able to recommend one I think that would be quite useful for the future.
Research in this field.
